Feature Stub

Recent:

Day 65 - Tumblr's Terms

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: In a recent update of their user terms, Tumblr gives you a range of plain language options when you select “No”

Why it’s good: There are few times that I feel more helpless as a user than when I’m looking at a EULA. I took a screenshot of the one that Apple popped up on my iPad recently, because it was 56 pages I would have had to read. Not happening.

Most desktop software handles this rather petulantly by requiring you to agree before using the software, and quitting without warning if you decline. Facebook and Spotify recently had to deal with massive public outcry when they changed their service terms without overt notice. They expected that users read them (as if anyone has) and went ahead as if everyone tacitly agreed by using the service. Not a great way to earn user trust.

Tumblr’s way of getting that agreement feels far less draconian. It still sucks that I have to read 3 tab panes of endlessly scrolling content in a modal window(Hint: They don’t expect me to) but the casual lead in copy makes it feel less scary.

The best part is what happens when you decline. Instead of yelling at you and throwing the modal window back in your face, they actually give you options that consider what you would want if you actually decline. They give you options to end your relationship with them! They give you options to reach out for clarification! They clarify that you actually need to accept if you are going to use the service—but in human and gentle tone!

Unless you are designing for lawyers, (and honestly, even when you’re designing for lawyers) don’t speak to your users like they’re lawyers. Tumblr seems to get that.

Day 64 - Amazon's Dashboard

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Amazon recently released a dashboard that pops up on your account page with a bunch of high-level data.

Why it’s good: As a retailer, Amazon’s diversity is one of its main selling points. As they begin subsuming more lines of business, they have created a problem for themselves on the account page. How can a single page encompass the enormity of your relationship with the company?

This dashboard highlights a step in the right direction. The majority of the information on it is directly relevant to me, and is stuff that I would frequently be looking for. The true success, though, is in the wonderful links under each snippet of data that tell me exactly how to interact with it. I’m most impressed with the “Subscribe and Save” where it indicates that an order is coming while selling it as savings, and yet still telling you when it will trigger. It breaks down a little bit in some areas, like the audiobook sell, but the intra-product advertising doesn’t feel heavy-handed here. It’s really that balance of information and action that makes it so successful.

Day 63 - DigitalOcean's Droplet Setup

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: DigitalOcean sells virtual machines that they call “droplets.” Their Droplet setup process is simple, streamlined, and easy to move through.

Why it’s good: I’ve seen a few iterations of this form over time, and each time DigitalOcean redesigns it becomes clearer and more streamlined. It’s a wonderful example of iterative design.

There are obviously great decisions in how direct and simple the form is the form is: the order that it asks the questions in (Name, Size, Location, Software, Other Settings, Expert Stuff,) the great inline validation and the helpful microcopy.

What ties this form together so well for me is the fixed right sidebar. It functions as a mini navigation, tells you how long the form is, and what you selected for each option. It’s something that feels scalable too—an element that’s greatly flexible depending on form length and complexity.

Day 62 - Warby Parker's Phone Service

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When I ordered glasses last year, I called for some clarification. Someone picked up the phone after one ring.

Why it’s good: Experience is grander than interface. Warby Parker’s site is nice. I didn’t have many problems ordering things. Their home try-on service was so amazing that it spawned a whole line of copycats.

However, their commitment to good customer service (or, if you will, customer experience) shows in the way that they structure their entire company. Having someone pick up the phone as soon as it rang shocked me so much that I was momentarily speechless. I had to apologize because I was in the middle of looking up my order email because I expected to be on hold.

When you are designing experiences, it isn’t enough to just take business decisions and turn them into interfaces. The interfaces will not fulfill every need, and then the user will fall back on those business decisions, for instance when they contact support. Consequently, we have to root all of our arguments in a user-centered philosophy to help us advocate for users through their entire relationship with our product.

Day 61 - The Lightning Design System

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: The Lightning Design System is the pattern library and styleguide for Salesforce.

Why it’s good: If you’ve been watching the design community, you may have noticed a huge focus on pattern libraries. The Lightning Design System made a big splash, and the US Web Design Standards were greeted with intense fervor.

These design systems are so fantastic because they are moving us away from designing pages. The challenge with experience is that it’s not defined by a single point; it’s the sum total of an entire relationship. Designing individual views is too small, too limited in scope to shape a user’s experience.

Lightning Design System’s designers took time not just to document what the implementation looks like, but also to go into great detail to explain how. There are numerous types of documentation for each pattern: visual, code, and verbal. Each version of it explains what it is, how you get it, and why they did it this way. It’s broad and detailed, but without being so precise that it requires designers to implement every decision.
